Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: FutureProofing Natural History Collections: Creating Sustainable Models for Research Resources; Fall, 2016, New Haven, CT
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural history museums are a treasured resource for public education and enjoyment. Less well-known to the general public, but critically for American science, they house millions of specimens and large quantities of data that are used by researchers to answer a range of questions relating to human health, agriculture, land management, conservation, and national security. Collectively, they form one of the largest scientific research facilities in the world, but the majority of the operating expenses of this national system are born by nonfederal organizations, both private and public, which in many cases struggle to meet these costs. If museum collections are to rise to the challenges facing society in the 21st Century, there is an urgent need to develop new economic models of operation.

This workshop brings together a diverse, interdisciplinary group of natural history museum curators and collections staff, collections users (both current and potential), sustainability experts, management research specialists, and future studies experts to discuss the potential for developing (1) quantitative measures of collections value and (2) economic models for translating this value into support for collections, based on tangible benefits. The agenda will foster an entrepreneurial approach to sustainability, encouraging participants to develop a variety of new business models in the context of long-term trends shaping society in order to secure the future of natural history museums and collections. The results of this project, including a white paper, will be available at www.esa.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural history collections are widely recognized as vital resources for biological research and education. Developing new financial models to sustain museum collections is critical to their long-term success and continuing ability to innovate in the face of funding challenges, emergent technologies, and expanding user expectations. This project brought together managers and users of museum collections to explore new ways of demonstrating collections value, and to examine the impact of future technological and social trends on collections use and audiences.

An initial workshop convened a diverse, interdisciplinary group of natural history museum curators and collections staff, collections users, sustainability experts, and future studies experts to discuss how to measure collections value and translate this value into support for collections, based on tangible benefits. Participants developed a variety of new business models in the context of long-term trends shaping society.

A key aspect of this project was developing value propositions that respond to different audiences in the context of future trends. We believe this effort has formed the foundation of a wider discussion within the collections community about new modes of operation that will improve collections access for research and education. We also believe that, by fostering the development of multiple new business models, this project has helped to 1) make sustainability planning a more explicit element of natural history collections management, and 2) enhanced the ability of collections managers to plan for the future.
